title: How to Clean Baby Bottles That Have a Milk Odor

steps.title: Wash the bottle with warm water and detergent.
steps.content: Wash the bottle with warm water and detergent. [2] X Expert Source Rebecca Nguyen, MA International Board Certified Lactation Consultant Expert Interview. 10 June 2019. Try to also remove any visible milk residue on the bottle by rinsing it out several times with warm water and detergent.

steps.title: Add a tablespoon of baking soda into the bottle.
steps.content: Add a tablespoon of baking soda into the bottle. Then, fill the bottle up halfway with warm water. If you fill the bottle completely with water, it will be hard to shake up the contents in the bottle because there is no free space in the bottle.

steps.title: Close the bottle with a lid and shake the contents of the bottle.
steps.content: Close the bottle with a lid and shake the contents of the bottle. Shake it for about 2 minutes.

steps.title: Rinse the bottle and smell it.
steps.content: Rinse the bottle and smell it. If the bottle no longer smells like sour milk, you have sufficiently cleaned the bottle.

steps.title: If the odor remains, soak the bottle in the water with baking soda.
steps.content: If the odor remains, soak the bottle in the water with baking soda. Find a container that can fit the entire bottle. Then, pour baking soda into the container. For each cup of water, add a teaspoon of baking soda and mix well.

steps.title: Place the bottle and all its parts into the container.
steps.content: Place the bottle and all its parts into the container. Fill the bottle with water from the container as well. Press the bottle parts, including the nipple, with a plate or some other heavier object so the bottle parts are submerged.

steps.title: Leave the bottle submerged overnight and then rinse it out in the morning.
steps.content: Leave the bottle submerged overnight and then rinse it out in the morning. Smell the bottle to confirm the odor is gone. [3] X Research source Let the bottle air dry before using it again.

steps.title: Make a solution of one part white vinegar and three parts warm water.
steps.content: Make a solution of one part white vinegar and three parts warm water. Then, fill the bottle with the solution. You can also fill a container large enough to fit the bottle and all its parts with the solution. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Ensure all parts of the bottle are soaked and submerged in the solution.
steps.content: Ensure all parts of the bottle are soaked and submerged in the solution. You can do this by pressing the parts down with a heavy object like a plate.

steps.title: Let the bottle and its parts soak in the vinegar solution overnight.
steps.content: Let the bottle and its parts soak in the vinegar solution overnight. In the morning, rinse the bottle and all its parts with water and detergent. The smell of vinegar may be present for a few minutes, but it will quickly evaporate.

steps.title: Check that the bottle can go in the microwave.
steps.content: Check that the bottle can go in the microwave. It should be marked with a “microwave safe” label. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Wash the bottle well with warm water and detergent.
steps.content: Wash the bottle well with warm water and detergent. Make sure you rinse out all the detergent.

steps.title: Fill the bottle halfway with water.
steps.content: Fill the bottle halfway with water. Then, separate the bottle parts and put them in a microwave safe bowl.

steps.title: Fill the microwave safe bowl with enough water to cover all the bottle parts.
steps.content: Fill the microwave safe bowl with enough water to cover all the bottle parts. Place the bottle and the bowl with the bottle parts in the microwave and turn it on for 90 seconds. Do not remove the bottle from the microwave until it cools to avoid burns.

steps.title: Sterilize the bottle using the stovetop.
steps.content: Sterilize the bottle using the stovetop. Get a pan with a lid, large enough to fit the bottle and all its parts. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Fill the pan with water and place the bottle and all bottle parts in the water.
steps.content: Fill the pan with water and place the bottle and all bottle parts in the water. Then, cover the pan with the lid. Boil them for 10 minutes. You do not have to remove the sterilized equipment from the hot water until you plan to use it. So, this way, the bottle will remain sterilized.

steps.title: Put the washed bottle in the freezer overnight.
steps.content: Put the washed bottle in the freezer overnight. The cold temperatures will freeze the bacteria and remove the smell. For the best results, don’t put the bottle in another container or bag, but instead simply place it in the freezer.

steps.title: Add a few drops of mustard to the bottle.
steps.content: Add a few drops of mustard to the bottle. Then, add water and wash the bottle. Rinse the bottle well with lukewarm water. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Remove the milk odor with toothpaste.
steps.content: Remove the milk odor with toothpaste. Use a new toothbrush to do this or use a brush for washing bottles. Add a bit of toothpaste to the baby bottle and give the inside of the bottle a good rub with the brush. Rinse the bottle well with lukewarm water.

steps.title: Fill the bottle with one part vodka and four parts warm water.
steps.content: Fill the bottle with one part vodka and four parts warm water. The alcohol from vodka will remove bad odors. Close the lid and allow the alcohol to sit in the bottle for 2-3 hours. [8] X Research source Rinse the bottle really well to ensure no vodka remains in the bottle, as drinking alcohol can be detrimental to the health of your baby.

steps.title: Try cleaning the bottle with charcoal.
steps.content: Try cleaning the bottle with charcoal. This method requires a few days. Take active charcoal briquettes and crumble them into a small powder. Pour the charcoal into the bottle and fill the bottle with warm water. Close the lid and shake well. [9] X Research source Leave the bottle to sit with the charcoal mixture for 3-4 days. Rinse the bottle with the warm water and detergent.

steps.title: Rinse your baby’s bottle after every feeding using warm water and mild detergent.
steps.content: Rinse your baby’s bottle after every feeding using warm water and mild detergent. Take a bottle brush and give the bottle a good rub on the inside and outside. [10] X Research source Make sure you rinse the detergent residue from the bottle with warm running water until the water runs clear and there is no more detergent residue. Always choose a detergent with a mild odor so that in the process of rinsing and cleaning, the bottle does not absorb the detergent’s odor.

steps.title: Keep your baby’s bottles in the refrigerator to prevent bacterial growth.
steps.content: Keep your baby’s bottles in the refrigerator to prevent bacterial growth. Bottles that sit out at room temperature can develop bacteria, especially if they are still damp after washing or if they are left unwashed. [11] X Expert Source Rebecca Nguyen, MA International Board Certified Lactation Consultant Expert Interview. 10 June 2019. In the lower, colder temperatures of the refrigerator, bacteria in the bottle will grow much slower and much weaker. [12] X Research source In fact, bacteria may be responsible for the bad smell in your baby’s bottle.

steps.title: Prepare the bottle just before your baby’s feeding time.
steps.content: Prepare the bottle just before your baby’s feeding time. This will prevent the milk from spoiling in the bottle. [13] X Research source If your baby has not fed from the bottle yet, you can leave the bottle out at room temperature for up to two hours. [14] X Research source Prepared formula can be left in the fridge for up to 24 hours. [15] X Research source But ideally, you should prepare a fresh bottle for your little one every time they feed to prevent the development of harmful bacteria in the bottle. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Throw away any leftover formula in the bottle once your baby has finished feeding.
steps.content: Throw away any leftover formula in the bottle once your baby has finished feeding. However, you can keep any leftover breast milk in the fridge for up to 24 hours. Serve it to your baby for their next meal, but only once. If any breast milk remains when you feed your baby the second time, discard these leftovers. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Use glass bottles instead of plastic.
steps.content: Use glass bottles instead of plastic. Glass bottles will absorb fewer smells than plastic alternatives—if you are consistently finding a milk odor in your baby bottles, consider switching to glass bottles. [18] X Research source
